items.title: Stiefelhagen domina con due vittorie consecutive al Nürburgring
items.description: L'azione in pista di sabato sul leggendario Nürburgring ha regalato due emozionanti gare della NXT Gen Cup, tenendo i tifosi con il fiato sospeso con
items.body: Stiefelhagen domina con due vittorie consecutive al Nürburgring 10 Agosto 2025 NXT Gen Cup, Motorsports 0 L’azione in pista di sabato sul leggendario Nürburgring ha regalato due emozionanti gare della NXT Gen Cup, tenendo i tifosi con il fiato sospeso con battaglie serrate fino alla bandiera a scacchi. Il leader del campionato, l’olandese Lukas Stiefelhagen, è emerso come la stella della giornata, assicurandosi due vittorie consecutive. Quando i semafori si sono spenti sabato mattina presto, il leader del campionato Stiefelhagen si è schierato accanto al tedesco Lennart Wolf in prima fila. Wolf ha preso il comando al primo giro, guidando una lotta a cinque vetture che includeva anche Philipp Dietrich, Maxim Dacher e Alex Gustafsson. Eroismo all’ultimo giro The Race 1 podium Lo sprint si è rapidamente trasformato in una battaglia tattica di strategie push-to-pass, con i piloti che aspettavano il momento giusto negli ultimi giri. Proprio all’ultimo giro, Stiefelhagen ha eseguito una mossa decisiva su Wolf che si stava difendendo brillantemente, strappando la vittoria. Sono molto contento, ovviamente – ha detto Stiefelhagen dopo la vittoria in Gara 1. È stata una bella gara. È stato difficile sorpassare Lennart, ma sono riuscito a superarlo alla fine sfruttando la mia spinta negli ultimi due giri. La lotta per il podio finale è stata altrettanto intensa, con la LRT NXT1 di Philipp Dietrich con livrea Hankook che ha superato di misura Maxim Dacher al fotofinish per il terzo posto. Gara 2 – Dall’ottavo alla vittoria The Race 2 podium Il formato a griglia invertita ha messo il debuttante Pit Venanzi e Benjamin Mazatis in prima fila. Venanzi è partito bene con la sua vettura numero 88 con livrea Poynting e si è difeso con forza in curva 1 per tenere Mazatis alle spalle. Al terzo giro, Venanzi era ancora in testa, ma un Alex Gustafsson in rimonta era risalito al secondo posto con la sua auto con livrea Bondix argento, seguito da Mazatis al terzo posto. La situazione è cambiata al sesto giro, con Venanzi che ha perso terreno. Il contendente al titolo Maxim Dacher, partito quinto, ha preso il controllo della sua vettura con la livrea rossa e bianca Nathiko. Nel frattempo, Stiefelhagen, partito con cautela dall’ottava posizione, si è fatto strada costantemente. Nell’ultimo giro, si è trovato alle calcagna di Dacher e, ancora una volta, il tempismo perfetto nel push-to-pass si è rivelato decisivo. Stiefelhagen lo ha superato conquistando la sua quinta vittoria consecutiva nella NXT Gen Cup, stabilendo un nuovo record di campionato. La battaglia per il terzo posto si è scatenata tra Mazatis e Gustafsson, con lo svedese che alla fine ha preceduto il rivale e si è aggiudicato il suo primo podio in assoluto nella NXT Gen Cup, un traguardo emozionante per il diciottenne. Finalmente, dopo tante, tante gare, ho conquistato il mio podio – ha detto Gustafsson dopo la gara. Non riesco a descrivere la sensazione. Voglio ringraziare tutti coloro che hanno contribuito a rendere tutto questo possibile. Ma domani è un altro giorno, quindi andiamo a prenderne un altro”. Race 1 – results – Top 5: Lukas Stiefelhagen (NED) Lennart Wolf (DEU) Philipp Dietrich (AUT) Maxim Dacher (DEU) Alex Gustafsson (SWE) Race 2 – results Top 5: Lukas Stiefelhagen (NED) Maxim Dacher (DEU) Alex Gustafsson (SWE) Benjamin Mazatis (DEU) Lennart Wolf (DEU)

items.title: Sono BYD  EPT3 le 4 ambulanze elettriche di Egadi e Pantelleria
items.description:
BYD EPT3, furgone elettrico compatto di produzione cinese, è stato convertito in una piccola ambulanza elettrica. Quattro veicoli…
L'articolo So
items.body: BYD EPT3, furgone elettrico compatto di produzione cinese, è stato convertito in una piccola ambulanza elettrica. Quattro veicoli sono stati recentemente consegnati alle strutture sanitarie delle isole Egadi e di Pantelleria, dove sono stati adattati per rispondere alle esigenze del servizio sanitario locale. Tradizionalmente utilizzato da artigiani come elettricisti e idraulici, da commercianti e corrieri urbani, BYD EPT3 si presta facilmente a configurazioni personalizzate. In questa occasione, l’allestimento ha previsto l’integrazione completa di tutti i presidi sanitari indispensabili per il soccorso e il trasporto dei pazienti. L’iniziativa è parte di un progetto finanziato con le risorse del PSN, nell’ambito del programma “Isole Verdi”, che punta a trasformare le piccole isole italiane in laboratori di innovazione sostenibile, promuovendo modelli di sviluppo “100% verdi” e autosufficienti. Il furgone elettrico della BYD ha un’autonomia di 230 km. Sebbene possa sembrare limitata, è adeguata al contesto

items.title: Marquez domina, ma c'è più equilibrio tra le Case [VIDEO]
items.description: #lanotiziainprimafila di oggi prende spunti da una serie di dati pubblicati da Dorna sulle prime 12 gare. Viene sottolineato come tutte i costruttori
items.body: Per inviarci segnalazioni, foto e video puoi contattarci su info@moto.it #lanotiziainprimafila di oggi approfondisce alcuni dati pubblicati da Dorna. Nelle prime 12 gare del 2025, cinque piloti differenti hanno vinto almeno un GP, dieci sono saliti sul podio, nove hanno fatto almeno un giro in testa (e diventano dieci considerando anche la sprint), tutte cinque le Case Costruttrici sono salite sul podio (Ducati, Aprilia e Honda sul gradino puù alto), sono stati battuti nove primati della pista. Come era andata nel 2024? Qui andiamo ad analizzare quanto successo nei primi 12 GP nella passata stagione, per scorpire che... Che il campionato piloti è molto meno incerto, perché quest'anno c'è un dominatore seriale, ma l'equilibrio tra i costruttori è aumentato e se non ci fosse Marc Marquez sarebbe, probabilmente, un campionato molto incerto e avvincete. E' questa #lanotiziainiprimafila di oggi, vorrei sapere la vostra opinione. Podcast podcast MOTOGP Moto.it Quotidiano di informazione motociclistica Reg. items.title: Caldo record nella Ue: urgente abbassare il costo dell’energia
items.description:
Le ondate di calore, tra giugno e luglio, hanno spinto la domanda di elettricità a livelli record e…
L'articolo Caldo record nella Ue: urgente a
items.body: damiano l il 10 Agosto 2025 A parte costruire centrali SMR/AMR (pronte tra minimo 15 anni? ) come governo, Confindustria e alcuni partiti vogliono… nell’ immediato si può solo agire su drastica contrazione dei consumi ove possibile (erga omnes avviene coi prezzi kW elevati..ma penalizza solo le fasce deboli…persone e piccole aziende) OPPURE incentivare al massimo (tra normative, IVA leggera e detrazioni) le nuove installazioni di F.V. pubblico e privato… La mia casa è tutta climatizzata ..ma a carico del sole ☀️… più c’è caldo più uso gli split (ma solo in deumidificazione) Senza gravare sulla rete nazionale (solo 1kWh in meno di contributo al GSE 😉). Questa spesa è stata un ottimo investimento….e con gli attuali inverni (brevi e molto clementi) ancor più utile visto che gli split li uso anche in inverno, relegando la caldaia ad 1 ora di funzionamento al giorno (nella mia zona climatica una vera pompa di calore sarebbe poco utile ..e più energivora).Per rendere l’ Italia più resiliente occorre aumentare le F.E.R. ove possibile ed utile…con più agrivoltaico… più capannoni e parcheggi con tettoie FV (anche per ombra alle auto sottostanti!) e anche DIMINUIRE le Isole di Calore cittadine con più ombreggiature da zone verdi e viali alberati (che abbattono di 4/5 gradi sotto le loro fronde ! ) e diminuire al massimo il traffico veicolare (in particolare i motori ICE , soprattutto a gasolio, perché il 75% del loro pieno carburante va solo in Calore nell’ ambiente ! oltre ad inquinare l’ aria e diffondere rumore molesto (per chi è costretto a dormire con le finestre aperte).Questi ultimi 2 roventi anni di record temperature son solo i primi dei futuri decenni con temperature ulteriormente crescenti, purtroppo… Bisogna prepararsi molto velocemente… Rispondi

items.title: Cupra Tavascan 2025: prezzo, foto, dimensioni, allestimenti
items.description: La Cupra Tavascan 2025 è un SUV-coupé elettrico di segmento medio-grande, lungo 4,64 metri, largo 1,86 e alto 1,60. L’impostazione
items.body: ; ads.list.push(['adsContainer-ZeO1aXlu','ZeO1aXlu']); Auto cupra Cupra Tavascan 2025: prezzo, foto, dimensioni, allestimentiCupra Tavascan 2025: prestazioni, autonomia e prezzi del SUV-coupé elettrico di Simone Dellisanti9 Agosto, 2025 Cupra Tavascan 2025 La Cupra Tavascan 2025 è un SUV-coupé elettrico di segmento medio-grande, lungo 4,64 metri, largo 1,86 e alto 1,60. L’impostazione del corpo vettura privilegia una linea slanciata e aerodinamica, con un coefficiente di resistenza all’aria di 0,26. Nonostante il design sportivo, l’abitacolo offre spazio generoso per cinque passeggeri e un vano bagagli da 540 litri, dotato di doppio fondo e pensato per gestire anche carichi voluminosi. La piattaforma è la MEB del gruppo Volkswagen, già utilizzata per modelli come Volkswagen ID.5, Skoda Enyaq e Audi Q4 e-tron. Design esterno Il frontale si distingue per la firma luminosa a tre triangoli LED incastonati nei fari, mentre i fanali posteriori sono uniti da una fascia luminosa con il logo Cupra al centro. Il tetto ad arco, il parabrezza molto inclinato e il lunotto quasi orizzontale accentuano il carattere coupé, mentre le proporzioni solide e i dettagli aerodinamici contribuiscono a un aspetto muscoloso. Abitacolo e tecnologia All’interno spicca la consolle centrale sospesa a forma di “Y”, con piastra per ricarica wireless e due porte USB-C collocate alla base. Il sistema multimediale è gestito da un ampio display da 15 pollici, reattivo e ricco di funzioni personalizzabili, mentre la climatizzazione trizona utilizza comandi touch integrati nella parte bassa dello schermo. Il quadro strumenti digitale da 5,3 pollici, seppur compatto, è completato da un head-up display per una migliore visibilità delle informazioni di marcia. Il pavimento piatto e il divano posteriore largo permettono a tre passeggeri di viaggiare comodamente, anche nei lunghi tragitti. items.title: Volkswagen T-Cross 2025: prezzo, foto, dimensioni, allestimenti
items.description: La Volkswagen T-Cross è una crossover compatta a trazione anteriore, sviluppata sulla piattaforma e sulla meccanica della Volkswagen Polo. Con
items.body: ; ads.list.push(['adsContainer-ZeO1aXlu','ZeO1aXlu']); Auto Primo Piano Volkswagen T-Cross 2025: prezzo, foto, dimensioni, allestimentiVolkswagen T-Cross 2025, motori, allestimenti e prezzi del B-SUV urbano di Simone Dellisanti9 Agosto, 2025 Volkswagen T-Cross 2025 La Volkswagen T-Cross è una crossover compatta a trazione anteriore, sviluppata sulla piattaforma e sulla meccanica della Volkswagen Polo. Con una lunghezza di 4,14 metri, una larghezza di 1,76 e un’altezza di 1,58, si posiziona tra le vetture “a prova di città” grazie agli ingombri contenuti. Nonostante il formato compatto, offre un abitacolo spazioso e facilmente accessibile grazie alle ampie porte, mentre il bagagliaio, da 385 a 1281 litri, beneficia del divano posteriore scorrevole fino a 14 cm, aumentando la versatilità d’uso. Estetica e abitacolo Il design della T-Cross privilegia forme squadrate e proporzioni equilibrate, con elementi tipici dei SUV urbani come le barre sul tetto e i cerchi in lega di serie. All’interno, la plancia mantiene un’impostazione tradizionale e ordinata, con un display touch da 8 pollici per l’infotainment e, sulle versioni di fascia alta, un cruscotto digitale da 10,25 pollici configurabile. La posizione di guida rialzata, unita alle ampie regolazioni di sedile e volante, facilita la visibilità e il comfort nei lunghi tragitti. Le finiture, pur restando nella logica di un modello di segmento B, sono curate e ben assemblate. Motori e prestazioni L’offerta si concentra su due varianti del tre cilindri turbo benzina 1.0 TSI. -1.0 TSI 95 CV (70 kW): eroga 175 Nm di coppia, raggiunge una velocità massima di 180 km/h e consuma in media 5,5 l/100 km, con emissioni di CO₂ pari a 125 g/km. Abbinato a un cambio manuale a 5 marce, privilegia l’efficienza e la semplicità di guida. items.title: Subaru Impreza 22B: la leggenda del rally è in vendita, ma a che prezzo...
items.description: Questo esemplare di Subaru Impreza 22B, la più desiderata tra le regine dei rally di fine anni 90 è in vendita. Un'occasione più unica che rara, e il
items.body: Per inviarci segnalazioni, foto e video puoi contattarci su info@moto.it Le auto storiche, classiche - chiamatele un po’ come volete - e negli ultimi anni anche le “youngtimer”, le giovincelle tra i venti e i trent’anni si sa, ormai sono oggetto di quotazioni in rapida crescita verso le stelle. Una delle categorie certamente più colpita dalla caccia all’ultimo Euro, figlia di un’epoca il cui profumo oggi è quasi completamente scomparso, è quella delle protagoniste del mondo dei rally di fine ventesimo secolo. Un’epoca in cui il “win on Sunday, sell on Monday” la faceva da padrone, e recandoti in concessionario il lunedì potevi trovare davvero la macchina che il giorno prima aveva vinto - per esempio - all’Acropoli. Quell’ultimo rally - il Gruppo A e successivamente le primissime WRC - prima della radicale separazione tra vettura stradale e macchina da rally. Il “Deltone”, la Celica GT-Four, la Sierra, la Escort, la Lancer e... ah sì, lei - o lui - il “Subarone”. Quell’Impreza, erede della Legacy RS, portata in alto dai guanti di Colin McRae, Richard Burns, Carlos Sainz ma senza dimenticare gli italiani Piero Liatti e Andrea Navarra, anch’essi nomi fortemente associati alla berlina blu coi cerchi oro. Storia, epica, leggenda. Leggenda che oggi si fa pagare. Aggiungici che auto così oggi non ne fanno più, i prezzi del nuovo salgono vertiginosamente - e di conseguenza quindi anche quelli dell’usato - e la rarità, soprattutto di alcune edizioni, che alimenta ulteriormente l’acquolina in bocca e il risultato è una sana dose di lacrimucce ogni volta che apri un sito di annunci. Per una capostipite del nome - un’Impreza prima serie GC8, berlina col due litri EJ20 da 211 o 218 CV - non si scende sotto i €13.000/14.000. Naturalmente parliamo di esemplari importati e non ancora targati, e/o con tanta strada alle spalle o problemi di ruggine (d’altronde è giapponese anche lei, quindi molto legata alle tradizioni). Per una originale italiana si sale comodamente oltre i 20.000. Attenzione sicuramente al fatto che quasi sempre le italiane sembra abbiano percorso molta meno strada rispetto alle estere. E per la più desiderata invece dove si arriva? Senza dubbio, nella cultura popolare la più bramata è una delle quattrocento 22B, la coupè tre porte con i fianchi larghi, lo spoiler alto e il boxer EJ22 portato a 2200 cc. Se ne siete alla ricerca di certo non sono molte le occasioni per portarvene a casa una, o quantomeno provarci nel caso si tratti di un’asta. Al momento però, potreste dare un’occhiata a questo esemplare del 1999 (telaio 325/400) con 81.000 km in vendita a Pètange, in Lussemburgo. La richiesta? Quì siamo in zona sei cifre, ma sei cifre abbastanza abbondanti - €209.990. Impegnativo, certo, ma al contempo un affare se confrontato con la 22B più “salata” mai battuta all’asta: il telaio 000/400, originariamente posseduto dal grande Colin McRae e considerato uno di tre prototipi pre-produzione, è stato battuto ad un’asta di Iconic Auctioneers a Silverstone alla modica cifra di £480.500, equivalenti a circa €554.000. Subaru Via Montefeltro, 6/A Milano (MI) - Italia 840 078 078

items.title: Nuova Kia Sportage 2025: scende in campo e le ha tutte contro. Top e Flop
items.description: All’interno dei SUV di medie dimensioni, la coreana si rifà il look e sfida apertamente Hyundai Tucson e Nissan Qashqai. Come se la caverà?
items.body: Per inviarci segnalazioni, foto e video puoi contattarci su info@moto.it La Kia Sportage nel 2025 rappresenta l’esito di un percorso durato più di 30 i fari verticali LED, ora più sottili e tecnologicamente avanzati, disegnano un’identità luminosa distintiva anche al buio. La vista laterale conserva il baricentro basso e la larghezza pronunciata, che conferisce stabilità visiva, mentre i cerchi in lega da 17″ a 19″ – nei nuovi disegni – accentuano l’impressione di robustezza dinamica. I dettagli aggiunti al restyling, come gli specchietti con indicatori raffinati e i paraurti più scolpiti, completano un’immagine che riesce a essere contemporanea e funzionale. Nel panorama interno la Sportage fa un vero salto generazionale. La plancia abbraccia due display da 12,3″ inseriti in un’unica linea fluidamente integrata, che mostrano strumentazione digitale e infotainment. Il sistema supporta l'Apple CarPlay e Android Auto wireless, aggiornamenti OTA, e include il nuovo store app “Kia Upgrades” con funzioni aggiuntive da scaricare direttamente in auto. I rivestimenti salutano una nuova qualità: ecopelle, microfibra Dinamica, dettagli metallici sapientemente inseriti, a testimonianza di un’anima premium. Funzioni pensate per la famiglia, come la “Baby Mode”, sottolineano l’intento rivolto al comfort e alla sicurezza dei passeggeri più piccoli, senza rinunciare a fruibilità tecnologica e semplicità d’uso. items.title: Stipendio medico legale, la verità dietro i guadagni che pochi conoscono: scopri quanto incassano ogni mese
items.description:
Il ruolo del medico legale è fondamentale per il sistema giudiziario e sanitario, ma quanto guadagna esattamente questa
L'articolo Stipendio medico le
items.body: Sostenibilità Stipendio medico legale, la verità dietro i guadagni che pochi Dopo oltre dieci anni di Con incarichi Casi complessi, come autopsie giudiziarie o danni Perizie assicurative o medico-legali Collaborazioni continuative con tribunali o Professore associato o Valutazione del danno biologico in casi di invalidità, incidenti o malasanità;Redazione di perizie medico-legali per tribunali, compagnie assicurative, INAIL e INPS;Valutazioni psichiatriche forensi;Accertamento delle cause di morte in casi sospetti o violenti;Consulenze tecniche d’ufficio (CTU) e di parte (CTP);Verifica della responsabilità professionale sanitaria.Il medico legale collabora strettamente con magistrati, forze dell’ordine, avvocati e enti pubblici per fornire pareri tecnici e supportare le indagini, soprattutto quando le prove disponibili non sono chiare o richiedono un esame medico approfondito.Differenze con altre figure medico-legaliSpesso si confonde il medico legale con patologi forensi o anatomopatologi, ma le competenze sono distinte. Il patologo forense, ad esempio, è specializzato nell’esame delle cause di morte improvvisa o violenta tramite autopsie, mentre l’anatomopatologo si occupa dell’analisi dei tessuti per diagnosticare malattie.Il medico legale ha un ruolo più ampio, intervenendo non solo nelle morti sospette ma anche nel campo delle lesioni, del danno biologico e della responsabilità medico-sanitaria. items.title: US-CoastEX: Observation-based probabilistic reanalysis of storm surge and sea level extremes for the United States
items.body: Download PDF Data Descriptor Open access window.dataLayer.push({ }); Background & SummaryExtreme sea level (ESL) events caused by storm surge extremes pose a threat to many coastal populations and natural ecosystems1 especially when combined with high astronomical tides1,2. The most extreme storm surge events develop during major storms, such as hurricanes and/or powerful extratropical storms, when extreme winds and low atmospheric pressure push ocean water ashore1,2. Establishing robust estimates of storm surge and extreme sea level events with proper uncertainty quantification through statistical analysis of observational data is critical for coastal design and risk and adaptation assessments3. However, high-quality historical sea-level observations are only available at sites with tide gauges, leaving long coastal stretches without observational coverage3,4,5. Furthermore, most tide gauges contain only a few years, or decades, of data, thereby providing only a limited sample of extremes. They also usually comprise gaps and/or erroneous or incomplete readings during major storms such as hurricane events4,5,6. These limitations limit reliable estimates of the likelihoods of extreme events (and their changes over time) using site-by-site statistical analysis of observational data4,5,6.Global and regional storm surge hindcasts, and extended data-reconstructions from machine-learning methods, based on atmospheric reanalysis forcing fields provide spatially-continuous extreme data from which extreme value statistics can be obtained. However, such products tend to underestimate coastal storm surge extremes, partly due to their coarse resolution atmospheric reanalysis forcing that cannot properly resolve extreme values6,7,8,9 and generally exhibit spurious climate variability and trends due to interplays between model biases and changes in historical observational data in reanalysis products9,10,11,12. In addition, as with most tide gauge data, existing storm surge hindcasts generally cover a few decades, typically after 1980 when satellite records began to become available to constrain atmospheric reanalyses12. Spatial statistical approaches such as regional frequency analysis (RFA)13,14,15 offer an alternative to partially overcome several sampling limitations of traditional site-by-site analysis of storm extremes by fitting a particular extreme value distribution to sets of aggregated storm data pooled together (from tide gauges sites or model outputs) across coastal regions that are assumed to be coherent. However, while easy to apply, RFA approaches rely on subjective criteria to establish coastal sites with coherent extreme storm characteristics13,14,15 and suffer from unsubstantiated statistical assumptions (e.g., neglecting spatial inter-site dependences and relying on unrealistic regional limits that generate discontinuous extreme storm surge fields)13,14,15, which often result in unreliable estimates and/or misrepresented uncertainties.Recently, more advanced spatial models for storm extremes have been used to overcome such limitations by resolving spatial dependencies in extremes, and in turn, enabling sharing of data information across tide gauge sites, and enabling predictions of surge extremes for ungauged sites4,5,16,17. However, existing spatial models (and associated data sets) for the U.S. have relied on a limited number of long-term tide gauge data16,17, thereby suffering from similar problems as site-by-site analyses, and are limited to contiguous U.S. regions which creates a limited basis situation for future coastal planning5. These models have also assumed that surge extremes are stationary16,17 whilst surge extremes have been shown to have regional coherent and significant trends along widespread U.S. coastal regions18. These current limitations preclude robust flood risk assessment and cost-effective adaptation planning with potentially severe implications due to premature failure of flood defenses designed with erroneous predictions19. Consequently, there is an urgent need for more reliable and robust estimates of the occurrence probabilities of storm surge and sea level extremes with a rigorous treatment of uncertainty. This should also account for major storm extremes that happened in the past, but are not captured and resolved in commonly used coastal water level databases.Here, we present a new observation-based probabilistic dataset (“US-CoastEX”) of storm surge and sea level extremes along the entire U.S coastline by applying an established non-stationary spatiotemporal Bayesian Hierarchical Framework (BAYEX)4 to the U.S. tide gauge network18 between 1950–2020. The complete dataset comprises two different (2) a “process model” that accounts for underlying dynamics of the processes involved; and (3) a “parameter model” that considers the underlying uncertainties in the parameters and integrates any prior knowledge about the prescribed data and underlying processes. The hierarchical model structure enables the assessment of the joint distribution of the processes and parameters conditioned on the data (also known as the posterior distribution), while rigorously propagating the uncertainties underlying the data, processes, and parameters4. These types of Bayesian Hierarchical Models (BMH) have been applied across various science disciplines (e.g., hydrology20 and ecology21) to enable robust statistical estimates, especially in contexts characterized by data scarcity and high uncertainty.In modeling spatial inter-site dependences of storm surge extremes, BAYEX resolves residual dependence (sites with co-occurrence of storm extremes) and climatological dependence (sites with similar and/or consistent storminess but not necessarily co-occurrence of storm extremes). Residual dependence is resolved using a max-stable process4,16,22 (i.e., an infinite-dimensional generalization of a Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distribution) and storm climatological dependence is here captured using latent Gaussian processes with random effects and physical bathymetric covariates (continental shelf width estimated using Natural Earth 200-meter depth contour line)4. In other words, residual dependence implies dependence among annual maxima whereas climatological dependence reflects spatial association amongst the GEV parameters4. The marginal distribution at any particular site follows a univariate GEV distribution based on max-stable process theory, with parameters μ (location), σ (scale), and ξ (shape). The location parameter, μ, is modelled as a spatial time-evolving process (using an integrated random walk) to account for climatological storm frequency changes. The GEV scale and shape parameters follow a spatial-varying, stationary process. An extensive description of BAYEX including its formulation, implementation and testing, has already been provided elsewhere4,14, and thus we only provide a brief description of its observation and process model layers. The likelihood can be written as4,22:$${Y}_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right)|{\theta }_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right),{\mu }_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right),\sigma \left({s}_{i}\right),\xi ({s}_{i}),\alpha \sim {GEV}\left({\mu }_{t}^{* }\left({s}_{i}\right),{\sigma }_{t}^{* }\left({s}_{i}\right),\alpha {\xi }^{* }({s}_{i})\right),$$ (1) $${\mu }_{t}^{* }\left(s\right)={\mu }_{t}\left(s\right)+\frac{\sigma (s)}{\xi }\left({{\theta }_{t}\left(s\right)}^{\xi (s)}-1\right),$$ (2) $${\sigma }_{t}^{* }\left({s}_{i}\right)=\alpha \sigma \left(s\right){{\theta }_{t}\left(s\right)}^{\xi \left(s\right)},$$ (3) where \({Y}_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right)\) is the annual maximum surge (m) for year \(t\) at site \({s}_{i}\), and \({\theta }_{t}\left(s\right)\) is a spatial process resolving residual dependence and \(\alpha \) ∈ (0,1) is a parameter that controls the relative contribution of small-scale errors. The GEV shape parameter, ξ, is allowed to vary in space, according to a Gaussian process18:$$\xi (s) \sim GP(\underline{\xi },c(s,s{\prime} ;{\gamma }_{\xi },{\rho }_{\xi })),$$ (4) where \(GP(\underline{\xi },c(s,s{\prime} ;{\gamma }_{\xi },{\rho }_{\xi }))\) is a Gaussian process with mean \(\underline{\xi }\) and covariance function c(,∙). The hyperparameters \({\gamma }_{\xi }\) and \({\rho }_{\xi }\) denote, respectively, standard deviation and length scale values defining the covariance function4.The GEV location parameter \({\mu }_{t}\left(s\right)\) is assumed to vary smoothly through time (to resolve long-term changes such as nonlinear trends as opposed to shorter-term variations, which are likely unresolvable) using a spatio-temporal integrated random walk according to4:$${\mu }_{t}\left(s\right)={\mu }_{t-1}\left(s\right)+{\mu }_{{trend},t-1}\left(s\right),$$ (5) $${\mu }_{{trend},t}\left(s\right)={\mu }_{{trend},t-1}\left(s\right)+{\omega }_{t}\left(s\right),$$ (6) where \({\omega }_{t}\left(s\right)\) is a zero-mean Gaussian process \({\omega }_{t}\left(s\right) \sim {GP}\left(0,c\left(s,s{\prime} ;{\gamma }_{\mu },{\rho }_{\mu }\right)\right)\).The extended description of all BAYEX process layers and parameters, including all Gaussian processes and initial states of \(\mu \), see refs. 4,5. The full description of the BAYEX spatial domain and the statistical inference process and model diagnostics analysis has been provided in ref. 18. In total, 6,000 distribution samples (post-warm-up draws for analysis) are provided by BAYEX (after a warm-up phase) for gauged and ungauged sites along the U.S. coastline (Fig. S1)18.Observational data for BAYEXUS-CoastEX includes extreme skew surge distributions (Fig. S3 shows posterior-median and 90% credible intervals) in addition to ESL estimates derived through BAYEX based on annual maximum skew surge data obtained from different data sources (Tables S1-S2) as shown below and illustrated in Fig. 1.Fig. 1Methodological framework diagram. The orange-shaded section displays the general workflow used to generate BAYESL-TG/EXT while the blue-shaded section shows the general workflow used to estimate the extreme sea level data from BAYESL-TG/EXT. The application of BAYES-TG uses only annual maxima skew surge data from observed hourly tide gauge sea-level records (as shown by the dashed violet line and the asterisk ‘*’).Full size imageStandard version (BAYESL-TG)In the standard application of BAYEX (henceforth BAYESL-TG), the model is informed solely by historical time series of annual maxima skew surge (used synonymously with storm surge) derived from high quality hourly sea-level records (1950–2020) from 208 open-coast tide gauge sites included in the GESLA-2 (Global Extreme Sea Level Analysis) database (retrieved {G}_{r}\left(z-x\right)f\left(x\right){dx}$$ (7) where \({G}_{r}\) is the (GEV) distribution of extreme skew surges and \(f\) is the density function of the tidal peaks over a full 18.61-year nodal tidal cycle. This approach assumes skew surge and tide independence with an equal probability of a given skew surge occurring at any high tide28. We convolve 6,000 skew surge distribution samples from BAYEX with tidal peak data, generating a total of 6,000 ESL return period curves from which posterior-median values and associated 90% credible intervals are calculated. The second approach (henceforth Method 2) adds a fixed tide level (such as Mean High Water (MHW), Mean Higher High Water (MHHW), or Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT)) (Fig. S6) to estimates of extreme surge levels9,23. Although we use Method 1 as reference in this analysis, we also provide alternative ESL estimates derived using fixed tide levels MHW, MHHW, and HAT (Fig. S6), aligning with previous research15,29; but other tidal levels could be used. The observed tidal peaks at gauged locations are obtained from GESLA water level time series via harmonic analysis (using the same time series from which annual maxima skew surge levels are obtained to inform BAYEX). Fig. S5 shows a comparison of 100-year ESL events derived using the different alternative methods at tide gauge sites using GESLA-based tidal peak data. The comparison shows that Method 1 (convolution) and Method 2 (when adding MHHW to estimates of storm surge return levels) result in consistent 100-year ESL return levels almost everywhere (differences of less than 0.20 cm); except along macro-tidal coastal regions where tidal influences dominate over maximum surge levels (e.g., Gulf of Alaska and/or Bay of Fundy). The 100-year ESL return levels obtained using HAT (Method 2) illustrate a very conservative (assume that extreme surge events always happen during HAT29) and exceed estimates from Method 1, everywhere, particularly on coastlines with considerable tidal ranges as mentioned before.At ungauged sites, high tide values are derived by applying harmonic analysis to the barotropic tidal TPXO9-atlas model (version 5) dataset, a product that exhibits a very small deviation ( 4 m; Hazel, Katrina or Camille) and other relevant events that do not exist in tide gauge records along with other relevant storms that have not been fully represented (and hence underestimated) by standard hourly tide gauge data result in much higher estimates compared to our standard BAYESL-TG version data (see Fig. 4; Fig. S4). Although we derive annual maxima skew surges only for storms with reported locations and datums (as previously mentioned), there is a degree of uncertainty introduced for specific inferred extremes and high-water marks where processing techniques have been applied (e.g., gap-filling procedures from NOAA) or when the exact peak time of major hurricanes are not reported (e.g., SURGEDAT) and therefore daily tidal peak needs to be averaged to derive skew surge estimates. It could also be possible that the few high-water marks labeled in SURGEDAT as storm-tides (without wave breaking influence) might still contain a wave-related component. It should be noted, however, that these uncertainties are rather small relative to the uncertainties associated with storm surge levels resulting from major storms. This is the case of many coastal areas exposed to major TC events (e.g., U.S. Gulf coastline) where storm surge extremes exceed 4 m (e.g., Carla, Camile, Katrina and Rita; Fig. S4) and differences between tidal peaks are extremely small (Fig. S6).Model spatial knot gridThe Bayesian hierarchical model rigorously propagates the underlying uncertainties associated with the prescribed extreme data, processes and parameters. However, some considerations on the uncertainties associated with how we model residual dependence need to be discussed. The spatial residual process is expressed as a linear combination of scaled Gaussian kernels defined on a grid of spatial knots4, converging to a max-stable process asymptotically as the number of knots grows infinitely large. Here a consistent 0.5-degree knot grid covering the U.S. coast has been used to resolve the spatial residual process18, corresponding to the length scale and spatial extend of traditional historical TC storms (~500 km). The residual process is built using all the knots at each tide gauge location. The length scale of the spatial residual dependence represents the spatial distance over which the residuals (differences between observed vs predicted values) remain correlated4, representing how far spatial influences persist before becoming negligible. Increasing BAYEX grid knot to 0.2 degrees or less could yield even more precise estimates for particular areas. However, such an increase comes with trade-offs as it is only computationally tractable by building the residual process using the nearest ten knots to each tide gauge station. Regional sensitivity analysis conducted for Florida indicates that increasing BAYEX grid knot from 0.5 to 0.2 degrees (while using ten knots at each tide gauge location) results in a reduction of the location (μ) and scale (σ) parameters by< 5% and the shape parameter (ξ) by ~15% when average across all tide gauge sites. While this increase in resolution could help resolve smaller length scales, the reduction in the number of spatial knots used decreases the ability of BAYEX to capture important regional dependence along many coastal regions. For example, in the U.S. South and East Coasts and Gulf Coast, major TC storms often track coastlines for hundreds of miles, affecting multiple tide gauges relatively far apart. Neglecting such regional dependences results in underestimated GEV parameters within such regions, particularly ξ18.Technical ValidationThe adequacy and performance of BAYEX (and its underlying max-stable process) have been comprehensively assessed using tide gauge records, modeled storm surge simulations and synthetic storm data4,5. The max-stable assumption in BAYEX for representing storm surge extremes has also been confirmed through leave-one-out cross-validation based on tide gauge observations4,5. A full comparison of BAYEX skew surge (GEV) distribution parameters (and associated return period estimates) against estimates from conventional at-site GEV model based on Bayesian inference have been conducted for 208 tide gauges along the U.S. coastal areas18. Below, we compare our convoluted ESL return levels using BAYEX and TPXO9v5 data against published or reported estimates from different data set available.Comparison of ESL estimates against NOAA observational estimatesHere we compare ESL return levels estimated based on BAYESL-TG/EXT data with published estimates using different data sets and statistical approaches. First, we compare 100-year ESL return level predictions from convolving BAYESL-TG/EXT extreme skew surge distributions and GESLA-based tidal peaks with values estimated by NOAA via regional frequency analysis (RFA)14 (https://sealevel.globalchange.gov/resources/2022-sea-level-rise-technical-report/) of tide gauge records (Figs. 4, 5). The comparison shows that 100-year ESL estimates presented here exceed estimates from NOAA for most tide gauge sites along the U.S. East and Gulf coasts by up to 1.5 m, depending on locations. The differences found at tide gauge sites along the U.S. West coast, Hawaii and Alaska are relatively small (i.e., typically less than 0.25 m) as extreme sea levels are generally dominated by high tides. A comparison of other return periods (25, 50, 75; and 100 years) is also presented highlighting that differences between estimates are already considerable beyond 25-year return periods for the U.S. East and Gulf coastline regions (Fig. 6). We note that there are multiple factors that can contribute to those differences, e.g., number and/or location of tide gauge sites, from which data was extracted, and their record lengths (as well as other data sources used to complement such records), differences in the data processing steps, spatial model used and estimation methodology for calculation of ESL return periods (as shown in Table S1). It is impossible for us to isolate the differences due to the use of different statistical models, unless the exact same data sources, time period and data processing methods are used.Fig. 5Difference (m) between 100-year ESL return level estimates derived by convolving BAYESL-TG/EXT extreme skew surge distributions and GESLA tidal peak data against estimates reported by NOAA using RFA across different tide gauge sites. Only common tide gauge sites are shown. The latitude and longitude scales are as in Fig. 2.Full size imageFig. 6Comparison of 25, 50, 75 and 100-year ESL return level estimates (m) against those reported by NOAA for each region. Estimates are all relative to present-day mean sea level (MSL).Full size imageComparison of ESL estimates against numerical model-based estimatesWe also compare BAYESL-TG/EXT return periods obtained through Method 1 with estimates calculated from a widely-used storm-tide model hindcast dataset (CODEC)34 covering 38-years between 1979–2017 (Table S1). This enables a comparison along the entire coastlines and not just for tide gauge sites. The extreme surge distribution estimated from CODEC data is derived by fitting a traditional GEV to annual maxima skew surge (m) time series for each model point separately (through maximum likelihood estimation), from which ESL return periods are then calculated through convolution based on tidal peaks from TPXO9, for direct comparison. Figure 7 compares 100-year ESL estimates through Method 1 and CODEC for all U.S. coastal regions. These results show that 100-year ESL return levels estimated from BAYESL-TG/EXT exceed site-by-site CODEC estimates for approximately 87% of the U.S. coastline by 65% on average. Similar results are found when fitting a Generalized Pareto Distribution (GPD) to CODEC data (not shown for simplicity). The exception is from Georgia to South Carolina, where single-site CODEC 100-year ESL estimates exceed BAYESL-TG-EXT based on Method 1 by up to 0.5 m (Fig. 7). In Fig. S7, we present return periods (years) using BAYESL-TG-EXT data for ESL that are estimated to have a 100-year return period based on at-site100-year ESL return levels based on CODEC data, indicating that (on average) extreme events of that magnitude are nearly three times more likely to actually occur (i.e., a 35-year return period event) as estimated from BAYESL-TG/EXT data. In many major coastal cities, such ESL events are up to 20 times more likely according to our results (e.g., New York, Tampa, Miami, San Francisco, Boston, Seattle and Honolulu; see Fig. S8). These considerable differences originate from the use of different data sources (observational archives versus simulated data; as shown in Fig. S9) and statistical methods (spatio-temporal BHM modeling versus traditional at-site analysis of surge extremes) as previously shown in ref. 18 (Table S1). In addition, we show a comparison against published 100-year ESL estimates retrieved from COAST-RP (https://data.4tu.nl/articles/_/13392314)35 - which have been obtained empirically from numerical surge simulations forced with synthetic storm tracks from a TC-database (STORM)38 and extra-tropical storms from ECMWF’s ERA5 reanalysis forcing35 (Fig. S10). We detect nearly identical differences (ca. Figure 7 and Fig. S9) with 100-year return level estimates from BAYESL-TG/EXT exceeding COAST-RP estimates for 76% of the U.S. coastlines by 50% on average.Fig. 7Comparison of 100-year ESL return levels (m) derived by convolving BAYESL-TG/EXT and TPXO9 tidal peak data with estimates from at-site GEV analysis based on CODEC data along the coastline of the U.S., Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. To facilitate visualization, only every grid point is shown. The comparison against COAST-RP (which includes synthetic storms) is provided in Fig. S10. The latitude and longitude scales are as in Fig. 2.Full size imageComparison of ESL estimates with FEMA total water levelsTo further contextualize our estimates, we provide comparison of 100-year ESL return levels based on BAYESL-TG/EXT against 100-year total water level return level estimates (referred to as stillwater elevation by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and includes astronomical tide, storm surge, and wave setup contributions) developed by FEMA39 to support floodplain management and flood insurance purchase requirements within the U.S. (Fig. S11). Despite not including wave setup, which can be a key contributor to coastal extreme stillwater elevations, we find that 100-year ESL return levels based on BAYESL-TG/EXT usually exceed or are on par with FEMA estimates for tide gauge locations along the U.S. Gulf and East Coasts. Our comparison is less useful for the U.S. West Coast, where wave setup is a major contribution to sea level extremes (relative to storm surge events). There, not surprisingly, FEMA 100-year total water levels (and referred by FEMA as stillwater elevation) exceed BAYESL-TG/EX ESL estimates. FEMA estimates hold considerable authority in the U.S. However, to our knowledge, very few comparisons have been made against other methodological approaches, including in terms of uncertainty propagation and/or quantification. We hypothesize that this may be due to the absence of a single, centralized dataset – data are dispersed across hundreds of FEMA Flood Insurance Studies - and the existing lack of a standardized approaches and/or metrics for storm surge and wave. Code availability The code that implements BAYEX is available in Zenodo37: de Moel, H. (Hans); Martinez, Andrew B.; Muis, S. (Sanne); Haigh, I.D. (Ivan) et al. STORM Climate Change synthetic tropical cyclone tracks. Version 2. 4TU.ResearchData. dataset.

items.title: Time series AQI forecasting using Kalman-integrated Bi-GRU and Chi-square divergence optimization
items.body: Download PDF Article Open access {_2}\), \(\hbox {SO}_2\), \(\hbox {O}_3\), \(\hbox {PM}_{10}\), \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\)) in the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood region. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements over baseline models (LSTM, CNN-LSTM), achieving an \(\hbox {R}^2\) of 0.96794, MSE of 4.11\(\times\)10\(^{-7}\), and MAE of 0.000423. This work advances AQI forecasting by addressing uncertainty, distributional alignment, and missing data within a unified architecture, providing a scalable solution for environmental monitoring and policy support. Similar content being viewed by others Enhancing urban air quality prediction using time-based-spatial forecasting framework Article Open access 03 February 2025 Prognosis of air quality index and air pollution using machine learning techniques Article Open access 17 July 2025 Air-quality prediction based on the ARIMA-CNN-LSTM combination model optimized by dung beetle optimizer Article Open access 26 July 2023 window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || []; window.dataLayer.push({ }); IntroductionOne of the most important issues facing the world today is air pollution, which has a substantial effect on human health, the environment, and economic stability. It originates from a variety of artificial sources that release toxic chemicals into the atmosphere, including industrial processes, vehicle emissions, and the burning of fossil fuels1,2,3. A standardized indicator that reduces complex pollutant concentrations to a single, easily interpretable number, the Air Quality Index (AQI) provides vital information for environmental policy and public safety4,5. Proactive health protection and urban planning rely on rapid and accurate AQI forecasts due to their direct correlation with respiratory and cardiovascular diseases. By creating a unique deep learning-based regression model that can handle missing data, capture uncertainty, and enhance temporal representation, this study seeks to solve the present shortcomings in AQI forecasting.The advent of technology has rendered the identification of AQI progressively dependent on Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL). Recently, researchers have utilized DL in medical imaging6,7, natural language processing8, and precision agriculture9,10. For time-series AQI prediction, traditional statistical models such as ARIMA have been frequently used; nevertheless, they struggle with multivariate data dependencies and nonlinear correlations11,12. Improved forecasting accuracy has been demonstrated with deep learning (DL) techniques such as LSTM, Bi-LSTM, CNN-LSTM, and hybrid models optimized by evolutionary algorithms (e.g., GA-ELM, BSMO)13,14,15,16. Many, on the other hand, struggle with overfitting, poor cross-regional generalization, or the inability to efficiently manage noisy and imperfect data. Although most models employ fixed techniques that overlook the dynamic uncertainty in environmental data, models that leverage attention mechanisms show promise in valuing temporal aspects17,18. Moreover, statistical divergence metrics are rarely incorporated into current loss functions to enhance forecast calibration. Recent research suggests a gap in the integration of distribution-sensitive learning and adaptive attention for AQI modeling19. Further highlighting the necessity for strong spatiotemporal frameworks that can generalize across locations while preserving forecast accuracy in noisy data situations are the results in20 and21.In order to close these gaps, this study presents a novel regression framework that improves distributional learning by combining Chi-Square Divergence with a Bi-Directional Gated Recurrent Unit (Bi-GRU) network and Kalman Attention. Kalman Attention refines temporal focus and increases robustness to noise by dynamically adjusting attention weights based on changing uncertainty, in contrast to static attention mechanisms22. Better model generalization and prediction stability are made possible by the Chi-Square Divergence component, which calculates the difference between the actual and anticipated pollutant distributions23. By addressing the issues of sequential dependencies, uncertainty estimates, and unbalanced pollutant dynamics within a single architecture, this combination represents a substantial improvement over earlier approaches.A two-stage pipeline makes up the suggested system. Prior to feature scaling to normalize pollutant concentrations, missing values are first imputed using the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model, which is based on temporal continuity. Second, the Kalman Attention Bi-Gated Recurrent Unit (Bi-GRU) model optimizes the prediction output by processing the sequential input and applying a regression layer that is aware of divergence. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) dataset is openly accessible, comprising hourly pollutant data (CO, NO2, SO2, O3, PM10, PM2.5) collected from the Denver–Aurora–Lakewood region for the period 2022–2024. The model is evaluated using metrics such as \(R^2\), Mean Squared Error (MSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) after being trained and validated using a rolling window technique.The following research questions serve as the basis for this {PM}_{2.5}\) by combining three ensemble methods with six independent time-series models. Using Pakistani city data from 2019 to 2023, the ESMV model generated daily forecasts that outperformed individual models in every location with exceptional performance metrics (MAPE 0.1679-0.2167, RMSE 20.32-48.31)36.The government highly recommends measuring AQI in polluted areas, and the proposed model37 offers an artificial intelligence-based data analysis method for air quality forecasting that integrates machine learning. It has combined the neural network and decision tree models to attain a high level of prediction accuracy. Similarly, research38 employed an LSTM and a deep autoencoder to forecast PM concentrations in South Korea from 2015 to 2018 while also assessing air quality on a weekly basis. The average PM concentration level has been predicted during a continuous 10-day period. The best DAE performance has been found at a batch size of 64. Experiments with the technology in question have demonstrated better prediction performance.10 created a multi-method framework to assess the effects of thermal power plant effluents on vegetation’s air quality by combining chemometric approaches, remote sensing, and machine learning. This hybrid approach demonstrates the effectiveness of combining environmental monitoring and artificial intelligence in understanding the ecological stress caused by pollutants. Similarly, Pragasan and Ganesan39 identified pollution-tolerant plant species for establishing greenbelts and assessed air pollutant concentrations. Their research serves as an example of a hybrid mitigation technique based on natural principles that aligns with the goals of predictive modeling.The prediction of air quality index (AQI) has been successfully enhanced by statistical and DL models in numerous studies. However, three critical challenges continue to they can lead to incorrect predictions and issues with real-time data. The Kalman Attention module in the modified Bi-Directional GRU is employed to facilitate efficient AQI prediction. This model has been specifically designed to match specific pollutant characteristics with available data on pollution collected using advanced training methods and self-feedback connections. To accommodate a longer series of input data, reduce the number of model parameters, and achieve greater efficiency, the Chi-square divergence is incorporated. The proposed approach can make efficient predictions by drastically reducing the model’s complexity, as it uses less memory, and the Bi-Directional GRU is faster to train. The amount of pollution concentration determines the AQI level as good, moderate, or severe. The dataset comprises hourly and daily AQI records from various stations in multiple cities. The data that the proposed model works with have the values of the concentrations of dangerous gases and AQI indices. Missing values are imputed, and the model is tested and trained. The prediction procedure is then completed using a regression analysis model. The proposed regression model captures AQI levels based on the concentrations of contaminants in the air by utilizing the novel Kalman Attention Bi-Directional GRU with a modified Chi-Square Divergence. The model is evaluated in terms of MSE and MAE as a measure of its performance, as indicated by metrics such as \(\hbox {R}^2\). By reducing the error in the discrepancy between the expected and actual AQI values, the model ensures more accurate forecasting based on all measurements.The general architecture of the suggested method for air quality forecasting is depicted in Fig. 1, which also includes information on the regression model pipeline, which includes ARIMA and Bi-GRU, and the data preprocessing processes (such as feature scaling and missing values checking). The complete stepwise modeling pipeline, including preprocessing, sequence generation, and the Kalman-Attention Bi-GRU regression with Chi-square Divergence, is formally presented in Algorithm 1.Fig. 1The overall structure of the suggested approach.Full size imageAlgorithm 1Kalman-Attention Bi-GRU with Chi-Square Divergence for AQI ForecastingFull size imageDataset descriptionThe dataset used in this study was obtained from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA, {NO}_2\) originate primarily from automobile emissions, a strong correlation is expected between these two pollutants. Similarly, \(\hbox {PM}_{10}\) and \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\) often display synchronized trends, as they share familiar emission sources.Comparison between the level of pollutants on holidays and on non-holidays was made as well, and general trends in the level of pollutants were analyzed. As the data show, the situation on public holidays typically does not reach the same high levels of pollution. As a result of reduced automobile pollution and industrial activity, it was indicated that the average concentration of CO during the holiday was 15% lower compared to that on non-holiday days. The average concentration of \(\hbox {NO}_2\) decreased by approximately 10% during the vacation period due to a decline in transportation and industrial activity. Pollution rates were observed to lower by 12–18% during holidays in cases of \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\) and \(\hbox {PM}_{10}\), meaning that pollution sources, e.g., industrial emissions and vehicle traffic, got reduced. The cause of this reduction in the number of pollutants is reduced vehicle traffic, industrial practices, and other anthropogenic sources of pollution, which were reduced on the days of public holidays, implying that public holidays provide an opportunity to improve air quality in urban air.These findings underscore the importance of adopting effective pollution control practices to mitigate the decline in urban air quality. The correlation of most pollutant pairings is shown in the correlation matrix in Fig. 4. The data was preprocessed in order to manage the missing records, remove negative or incorrect entries, and make the timestamps of pollutant categories match. Due to the high quality of EPA monitoring, slight imputation was required, and time synchronization enabled the creation of continuous, multi-pollutant profiles over a three-year period. The dataset is ideal for evaluating long-term pollution dynamics in an urban setting and examining temporal trends. There is a noticeable decrease in the average concentration of pollutants, which can be attributed to either regional mitigation initiatives or better emissions controls. Due to less atmospheric dispersion and increased fuel combustion for heating, there is significant seasonal variance. Early spring and winter are the dual seasonal peaks of several pollutants, which correspond with transportation emissions and weather inversions. Weekend concentrations are marginally lower, according to smoothed data, likely due to reduced traffic and industrial activities. Despite their subtlety, these cycles add to the data’s weekly autocorrelation. Consistent across all pollutants, there are notable decreases on national holidays (such as Thanksgiving and Independence Day), which may indicate less human activity. Post-holiday increases have some implications for rebound traffic and industrial impacts. Temporary jumps are associated with recognized environmental events, such as winter inversion layers and smoke from wildfires in woodland areas. The episodes are necessary to understand the highest exposure risks. In some cases, the data may be missing due to EPA sensor failures or quality control flags. These small gaps were filled in through linear interpolation without altering the temporal patterns. The dataset can be used not only to forecast trends but also to detect seasonal anomalies, as it exhibits complex temporal dynamics. The characterization enhances the reproducibility of time-series modeling and increases the transparency of data selection. Other theorists and practitioners have recommended practices in line with this extensive temporal decomposition procedure, as seen in40, which analyzes multi-scale trends and seasonal components of energy measurements, and41, which examines calendar effects in time-series forecasting. These websites provided valuable ideas concerning how to handle and present complex environmental data.Fig. 2Daily air quality from 2022 to 2024.Full size imageFig. 3Hourly, Daily, Weekly, and Monthly AQI Trends from 2022 to 2024.Full size imageFig. 4Correlation between Pollutants.Full size imagePre-processing with ARIMAData preprocessing includes feature scaling and checking for missing values. Where the missing data is somehow known, the data values of pollution are noted discretely. The forecasting and filling in missing data using the ARIMA model effectively addresses these missing values by employing an imputation method. Scaling the features reduces the model’s complexity. With ARIMA as the imputation method, the replaced data is considered more reliable, as patterns of the missing data are accurately forecasted by ARIMA, allowing for further analysis. Addressing missing values and feature scaling are two aspects of data preprocessing. Discrete values are used to store pollution data, and missing values are common in datasets. The study employed a column-wise imputation method utilizing AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) models as univariate time series for pollution data. The study commenced with Augmented Dickey-Fuller tests to assess stationarity, followed by data differencing when the tests indicated non-stationarity. A grid search method identified the optimal ARIMA(p, d, q) parameters for each pollutant by minimizing the Akaike Information Criterion, thereby achieving maximum accuracy while avoiding complexity issues. The experimental parameter constraints encompassed p ranging from 1 to 5, d between 0 and 2, and q from 0 to 3. The selected models were used to forecast and impute missing data points based on prior observations, thereby maintaining temporal relationships regardless of external factors. The post-imputation investigation indicated that the estimated values maintained pollutant behavior patterns and preserved both seasonal changes and periodic trends.The selected imputation technique employs column-wise ARIMA-based methods rather than conventional linear interpolation or mean replacement, as it concurrently addresses time-dependent correlations while producing accurate projections. The application of ARIMA preserved the distinct historical trends for each pollutant, which is crucial for subsequent forecasting activities reliant on pattern retention. ARIMA is utilized to predict and impute missing values by leveraging the temporal patterns in the dataset. ARIMA models time-series data derived from historical values and trends, and it predicts missing data points by fitting a statistical model to the observed data. Unlike GANs, which rely on a generative structure with a generator and discriminator, ARIMA directly imputes missing values by identifying the relationships Y_a=b+\sum _{x=1}^{p}{\phi _xY_{t-x}}+\sum _{y=1}^{q}{\theta _j\epsilon _{t-y}}+\epsilon _t \end{aligned}$$ (1) Let \(Y_a\) be the observed values \widehat{Y_t}=\hat{c}+\sum _{x=1}^{p}\widehat{\phi _i}Y_{t-i}+\sum _{y=1}^{q}\widehat{\theta _j}\epsilon \end{aligned}$$ (2) The constant term in the model autoregressive moving average can be estimated as \(\hat{c}\), whereas \(\widehat{Yt}\) is the highest value of the time series at time t. Autoregressive (AR) f is denoted by an autoregressive component of size p, i.e., the summation of all the terms \(\sum _{x=1}^{p} Y_{t-i}\). The moving average (MA) part with order q is coded as the \(\sum _{y=1}^{q} \epsilon _{t-j}\) and it is the contribution of past forecast errors \(\epsilon _{t-j}\) weighted by the estimated parameters \(\widehat{\theta _j}\). With data of time series values that are not moving, the model is effective. Imputation is performed based on the associations found in the surrounding data points.The ARMA model is employed to make predictions \(\widehat{Y_t}\) using the history of observed values and errors in forecasting. This normalization of variance makes the result easy to read, regardless of data scaling, and is widely used in data analysis, machine learning, and statistics related to the association of variables.Here, we present the thoughtful attention introduced by Kalman, a novel attention mechanism that differs significantly from the traditional attention process commonly found in existing models. Many standard attention designs, such as the Transformer architecture, use the connection of input tokens with the current state of the model. Ideally, the connection of input tokens to the current state of the model is used to calculate attention weights. These attention weights are determined independently of the level of data uncertainty, and they are either hard-coded or calculated statically on each time step. On the other hand, Kalman has included the Kalman filter, most frequently used to recursively implement state estimation in uncertain and noisy conditions, in the Kalman Attention. Unlike the case in conventional attention, the weights are dynamically alterable based on the level of uncertainty in the data by Kaman’s Attention. More reliable (not so noisy) data points are assigned higher attention weights, whereas less reliable (Noisy) data points are assigned lower attention weights. This enables the model to focus on the most relevant data, particularly in instances where data may be inconsistent or incomplete, as is often the case with time-series air quality data.Through an active update of the model uncertainty estimates, the Attention provided by Kalman enables the model to dynamically focus on an appropriate point of interest during the prediction process. This correction is particularly beneficial when working with environmental data, where readings of pollutants often fluctuate due to sensor malfunctions or other factors. The proposed model enhances its performance and robustness in estimating the ambient air quality, even in uncertain/noisy settings, by incorporating the Attention as proposed by Kalman.Kalman filterIn the process of discussing the role of weather in controlling the diffusion or settling of pollutants, the effect of different weather parameters on the AQI should be put into perspective. There are flaws and imperfections in the process of data collection of the variables, despite the decent data sources that take into consideration the dynamic status of the system under evaluation. A prediction-correction method is applied to achieve optimal estimation. In essence, the Kalman filter is a simplified autoregressive data processing technique that doesn’t require all prior data. Even with noise interference, it can forecast the next stage of a dynamic system in unpredictable circumstances. Estimation and correction of state variables are the two primary processes in the Kalman filter, in simple terms. The residual term indicates how far the prediction deviates from the actual observation.The primary objective of a Kalman filter is to provide the most accurate estimate of the system’s state by combining predictions with actual measurements. It utilizes both the model’s predictions and the observed data to correct and refine the state measurements. Another objective of the Kalman filter is to minimize estimation error by adjusting the predicted state based on the upcoming measurements. It does this by reducing the uncertainty of the state estimate, making it as close as possible to the actual state. This filter is designed to track dynamic systems and update forecasts as new data becomes available. It is beneficial for systems that evolve over time and for measurements that are noisy and incomplete. The Kalman filter is also helpful for error correction; it adjusts its state estimates based on the reliability of the measurement and prediction.Kalman attention-bidirectional GRU with Chi-squared divergenceWhen handling noisy data, the Kalman filter deals with uncertainty in both the prediction model and the measurement. Hence, it addresses both process noise and measurement noise, making it robust in real-world applications where handling large, noisy datasets is inevitable. To predict the environmental quality values in the data, including the collection of regions with their rates of air pollution, the Chi-square methodology is combined with the suggested idea of Kalman attention-based BiGRU.Experimental resultsExperimental setupHardware and software specificationsThe system features an AMD Ryzen 9 5900X processing engine, which offers strong multi-core performance capabilities for demanding tasks. It comes with 32GB of RAM, which facilitates easy multitasking and enables more efficient data handling, as well as a 1TB hard disk for storing large amounts of data. It comes with Windows 10 Pro, a stable and secure operating system. The experiment was conducted using the Python programming language, built on the PyTorch framework.ARIMA hyperparameterIn the ARIMA model used to fill in the missing value, a grid search was done to optimize the parameters of p, d, and q based on the AIC (Akaike Information Criterion). For most pollutants, the best responses were noted in the range, p in [1,3], d = 1, and q in [0,2], which effectively captured the temporal relations and avoided overfitting.Deep model hyperparametersTraining of the modified Attention model involved an application of a learning rate of 0.001 and 2 Bi-GRU stacked layers with 128 hidden units, a batch size of 32, and 100 epochs. The model implemented a dropout operation (0.3 dropout rate) to prevent overfitting between its layers. Adam training enabled the system, which utilized the mean squared error loss paired with the chi-square divergence regularization term controlled by \(\lambda\) = 0.2, set based on the evaluation of the validation set. Evaluation metrics include MAE, MSE, and \(\hbox {R}^2\) for measuring model accuracy and prediction quality.Evaluation metricesThe performance analysis and evaluation of a linear regression model typically rely on various indicators. One of them is the Mean Squared Error (MSE). Because MSE is particularly useful MSE=\frac{1}{n}\sum _{j=1}^{n}\left( y_j-\widehat{y_i}\right) ^2 \end{aligned}$$ (38) where number of samples denoted by n, \(y_j\) represents observed value, and \(\widehat{y_i}\) represents predicted value.While both MAE and MSE MAE=\frac{1}{n}\sum _{j=1}^{n}\left| y_j-\widehat{y_i}\right| \end{aligned}$$ (39) The best metric for assessing the model’s success is the coefficient of determination, or \(R^2\), which measures the degree to which the linear regression model’s projected values match the data. A higher \(R^2\) value indicates a model that better fits the data. The predicted value is represented by \(\widehat{y_i}\), R^2=1-\frac{\sum _{j=1}^{n}\left( y_j-\widehat{y_i}\right) ^2}{\sum _{j=1}^{n}\left( y_j-\bar{y_i}\right) ^2} \end{aligned}$$ (40) Statistical analysisThe Diebold Mariano (DM) test, a popular statistical method for assessing forecast accuracy across forecast models, was used to assess the model. The CNN-LSTM and LSTM baseline models were compared with the suggested model in this study. The p-value was 0.02, and the DM test statistic was -2.34 when comparing the Proposed Model to LSTM, suggesting that the Proposed Model’s increase in forecasting accuracy was statistically significant. According to these findings, the Proposed Model performs comparably to CNN-LSTM but noticeably better than LSTM. Overall, the presented model exhibits great generalizability and accuracy.Table 9 Comparative evaluation of AQI prediction models based on MAE and \(R^2\).Full size tablePractical implicationsThe proposed AQI forecasting model, utilizing a modified model architecture, offers significant improvements in predictive accuracy and robustness for air quality monitoring. However, for practical deployment in real-world settings, several challenges must be addressed. The model’s accuracy is heavily reliant on the data from air quality sensors, which are subject to various sources of error, including calibration issues and environmental interference. Ensuring the reliability of sensors in real-world conditions through regular calibration and maintenance will be critical for maintaining the integrity of predictions.Additionally, the deep learning techniques used in this model require substantial computational resources, particularly for real-time prediction. In practical deployments, leveraging edge computing or distributed systems may be necessary to meet the demands for processing power, ensuring that the model can scale for widespread use without compromising accuracy. Handling and processing large amounts of time-series air quality data in real time can present significant storage and processing challenges. Efficient data storage and retrieval systems will need to be implemented to handle high-frequency sensor data while ensuring minimal latency in prediction generation.The model was tested with data from specific regions such as the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood area. To be implemented in other areas, the hypothesis must be generalizable to other air pollution trends, local emission components, and sensor data peculiarities. There will be a need to enhance the model’s generalizability to other geographical locations in the future. The application of the AQI forecasting model in real-life practices will also involve compliance with local environmental regulations and data privacy laws, particularly when working with environmental and health-related information. As much as the model should be acceptable to people, it is necessary so that the model can be incorporated into the structures of public policies.Lastly, the infrastructure needed to implement this model of structure on a large scale, such as sensor networks, computational resources, and data storage, can be prohibitively expensive in certain geographic locations. To achieve widespread adoption, it will be necessary to develop affordable solutions and strategies that make them accessible to resource-strained societies. By eliminating these hurdles, the suggested system will become capable of handling tasks such as air quality monitoring, providing environmental policy guidance at both local and global levels, and implementing public health solutions and activities.ConclusionThe study proposes a new system that employs the attention mechanism of Kalman with a network of Bi-Directional Gated Recurrent Units (Bi-GRU), in which the loss function is optimized using Chi-Square Divergence. The methodology provides solutions to the most significant problems related to AQI forecasting, including the incorporation of temporal data dependency, handling missing data, and processing noisy or inconsistent data. The authors evaluated their proposed model on a day-to-day basis using pollution data from the U.S. EPA, which covers the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood area. The developed model was more effective than the traditional Bi-GRU, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM variations in experimental evaluation. An application of the modified attention model, based on the Chi-Square Divergence, resulted in necessary reductions of 15.3%, 12.7%, and 14.1% in MAE, \(\hbox {R}^2\), and MSE, respectively, compared to the best baseline model. The suggested model excels in capturing geographical and temporal patterns while identifying meaningful correspondences in multivariate records of the AQI dataset. We observed a distinct pattern of lower air pollution during holidays, which is consistent with the predictions of lower human activity, by measuring the variations in pollutant levels between holidays and non-holidays. This quantitative result provides insight into how human behavior impacts environmental health and validates the model’s ability to identify and measure changes in air quality over time. The suggested method exhibits a robust ability to monitor air quality in real-time and formulate operational strategies since it functions successfully with noisy and incomplete data. The forthcoming study will focus on developing a multimodal input system integrated with deployable edge computing for localized, time-sensitive predictions of air quality indices. items.title: A Festambiente presentato il XIV rapporto nazionale “Animali in città” e premiati gli “amici” degli animali
items.description: In Italia meno di 4 comuni su 10 raggiungono la sufficienza su servizi pet-care. Disparità tra comuni costieri e interni, specie su accesso ad aree l
items.body: 8 Agosto 2025 Legambiente 8 Agosto 2025 Comunicati stampa benessere animale , Festambiente A Festambiente presentato il XIV rapporto nazionale “Animali in città” e premiati gli “amici” degli animali 8 Agosto 2025 Legambiente 8 Agosto 2025 Comunicati stampa benessere animale , Festambiente In Italia meno di 4 comuni su 10 raggiungono la sufficienza su servizi pet-care. Disparità tra comuni costieri e interni, specie su accesso ad aree libere per cani, pensioni per animali e gestione fine vita In Italia, nonostante una domanda in crescita soprattutto da parte dei nuclei familiari più fragili, il benessere degli animali d’affezione e delle loro famiglie resta fuori dalle priorità delle politiche San Giovanni in Persiceto (BO) che eccelle grazie a servizi integrati, un forte attivismo civico e ordinanze comunali efficaci; Modena per l’investimento economico significativo e una regolamentazione urbana completa a tutela del benessere animale. Tra i Comuni sotto i 5.000 abitanti, premiati Zocca (MO) e Campodolcino (SO) per i loro investimenti in educazione civica e in progetti sociali adattati al contesto rurale e montano. Tra le ASL più virtuose, invece, si distinguono Napoli 1, Bergamo e Vercelli, che oltre a fornire dati puntuali, integrano meglio i servizi sanitari con quelli offerti dai Comuni, operando con proattività. “Il XIV Rapporto di Animali in città – dichiara Giorgio Zampetti, direttore generale Legambiente – conferma che solo grazie a solide alleanze tra amministrazioni pubbliche e soggetti privati è possibile garantire il benessere delle famiglie con animali d’affezione. Per questo chiediamo di promuovere ed agevolare la firma di 1.000 accordi o patti di comunità in tutto il Paese. È urgente rilanciare la sanità veterinaria pubblica di prossimità, obiettivo per cui chiediamo al Governo di realizzare un piano nazionale a supporto delle Regioni che consenta l’assunzione stabile di 6.000 veterinari e alle Regioni il raggiungimento complessivo di 1.000 strutture veterinarie pubbliche (850 tra canili sanitari e gattili sanitari e circa 150 ospedali veterinari pubblici), distribuite equamente sul territorio in rapporto alla popolazione servita. Inoltre, alle Amministrazioni comunali l’appello è di potenziare le aree verdi con libero accesso dedicate alle famiglie con cani, di valorizzare l’applicazione di regolamenti e ordinanze e rafforzare il senso civico grazie al supporto di 10.000 guardie ambientali e zoofile delle associazioni di volontariato, per migliorare concretamente la qualità della vita di cittadini e animali”. “Con il premio nazionale ‘Animali in Città’ – aggiunge Antonino Morabito, responsabile nazionale Cites e Benessere animale di Legambiente e curatore del rapporto – che Legambiente promuove ogni anno, vogliamo valorizzare l’impegno di Amministrazioni, ASL, associazioni e istituzioni che si distinguono per l’attenzione verso gli animali e mostrare i tanti casi positivi che dimostrano, concretamente, che anche in questo settore un’Italia al servizio dei cittadini e dei loro amici a quattro zampe esiste e lavora alacremente. Crediamo che questi esempi virtuosi possano rappresentare un modello e uno stimolo per rafforzare la collaborazione tra pubblico e privato, migliorando i servizi dedicati ai cittadini e ai loro animali da compagnia, a beneficio dell’intera collettività. Con lo stesso scopo, un’iniziativa e un impegno a cui teniamo particolarmente è la nascita della Rete nazionale dei Garanti per i Diritti degli Animali, figure nominate da Regioni e Comuni che svolgono un ruolo delicato quanto fondamentale. La messa in rete di queste esperienze è oggi un aiuto concreto all’avanzamento del Paese. Per questo motivo, da Rispescia, Legambiente lancia il prossimo appuntamento della Rete nazionale dei Garanti per i diritti degli animali che si terrà in autunno a Roma.” Alla conferenza di presentazione e premiazione dal titolo “Cura Pubblica, Responsabilità Condivisa. Sinergie tra Istituzioni, Garanti, Associazioni e Comunità: verso la Rete Nazionale dei Garanti per i Diritti degli Animali” hanno preso Angelo Gentili, segreteria nazionale Legambiente; Erika Vanelli assessore all’ambiente, delegata al benessere animale Comune di Grosseto; Marco Melosi, presidente Associazione Nazionale Medici Veterinari Italiani; Edgar Meyer, presidente Gaia e Ambiente; Michele Pezone, responsabile diritti animali Lega Nazionale Difesa del Cane; Michela Vittoria Brambilla, presidente della Commissione parlamentare per l’infanzia e l’adolescenza; Francesca Sorcinelli, presidente dell’associazione LINK-Italia e i Garanti dei diritti animali di Regioni e Comuni. Ha coordinato Antonino Morabito, Responsabile nazionale CITES e Benessere animale di Legambiente. Tra i prossimi appuntamenti con
